title: fanoutqa: Which members of the Sidemen have their own Wikipedia pages and where did they attend school? (03156f229dd08e0c)

chat_history.content: Which members of the Sidemen have their own Wikipedia pages and where did they attend school?

In October 2013, KSI signed with Maker Studios' sub-network, Polaris.[20] Since 19 October 2013, KSI has been part of the British YouTube group known as the Sidemen.[21][22][23] The group produces online videos, most often consisting of challenges, sketches and video-game commentary, as well as selling exclusive Sidemen merchandise.[24][25][26]


In 2015, KSI published a biography titled *KSI: I Am a Bellend*.[27] The book was released on 24 September 2015 in the UK and five days later in the United States, and KSI toured to support the book from its release until 4 October 2015.[28]

On 4 August 2017, KSI tweeted that he would be leaving the Sidemen, citing conflicts with fellow member, Ethan Payne.[*citation needed*] Shortly thereafter, he released a number of diss track videos criticising members of his then-former group, to which most of the members responded back with their own.[29] Later that month, KSI released a video in which he claimed that he was being deported from the United States for receiving an incorrect visa.[*citation needed*] In November 2017, KSI released a video discussing whether his supposed falling out with the Sidemen was real or fake, saying, "[the drama] wasn't entirely real but wasn't entirely fake either."[29]


In 2019, he was ranked second by *The Sunday Times* in its list of the top 100 UK influencers.[13] In 2020, *The Times* named KSI to be Britain's biggest influencer.[30]

**Olajide Olayinka Williams** "**JJ**" **Olatunji** (born 19 June 1993), known professionally as **KSI**, is an English Internet personality, professional boxer and musician. He is the CEO of Misfits Boxing and the co-owner of Prime Hydration, XIX Vodka, Sidemen Clothing, and a restaurant chain known as Sides.


</fragment>

<fragment>

KSI's rise to fame was not without controversy, with him being widely criticised for his self-described 'rape-face', a recurring joke on his channel during 2012 and 2013.[12] He was the centre of a controversy following third-party allegations of sexual harassment of female staff at a *Eurogamer* event in 2012, that went so far as accusing him of sexually assaulting a spokesmodel Brandy Brewer, despite her tweeting that she consented to the motorboat, writing, "it's called comedy……relax".[16][17] As a result, Microsoft cut ties with KSI and he was banned from *Eurogamer* events.[18] KSI subsequently apologised "for any offence the video of 15 months ago may have caused in the short time it was on his YouTube channel, references to it since and subsequently used by other people" and stated his desire to move on from the incident and "be judged on the great content and value he gives to brands and partners, without controversy."[19]



### 2013–present: Sidemen and expanding content[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

In March 2021, KSI faced criticism for misgendering a trans person and using a transphobic slur in a Sidemen video. He later apologised, claiming not to have known that the word was offensive.[31][32] In April 2023, KSI used the racial slur "*Paki* " in a Sidemen video parodying the British game show *Countdown*. He later apologised on Twitter and announced he was taking a break from social media. The video has since been removed.[33] He then visited the Al-Hikam Institute, a mosque in Bradford, to "educate himself" and where he apologised again for the hurt and disappointment he had caused.[34]


In September 2023, *Forbes* ranked KSI as the second top creator of 2023, earning an estimated $24 million.[35]



## Music career[edit]


### 2015–2016: Early releases[edit]

<fragment>

In 2020, *The Sunday Times* estimated KSI's earnings to be £12 million a year; a year later, they believed that his estimated earnings had gone up by another £13 million.[154][155]


He has been open about his investments in cryptocurrency, but he has reportedly lost almost £6 million. Since the losses, he has claimed to be done with crypto.[156]



## Philanthropy[edit]


In 2015, KSI donated $10,000 to an online charity stream done by YouTuber Castro1021, and he participated in the Race Against Slime event, raising money for SpecialEffect, a foundation developing technology to aid people with physical disabilities to play video games.[147] Between 2016 and 2022, KSI and the rest of the Sidemen hosted and participated in four charity football events, raising just shy of £400,000 for various charities, including the Saint's Foundation, Childline, Young Minds and the Charlton Athletic Community Trust.[157]

**Vikram Singh Barn** (born 2 August 1995), better known as **Vikkstar123**, is an English YouTuber and Internet personality. He is a member and co-founder of the Sidemen, a British YouTube group.




## Early life and education[edit]


Barn is of Indian descent[3] and was born on 2 August 1995[4] in Guildford, Surrey, England,[5] where he lived until eight years of age.[6] He later lived in Sheffield where he attended Silverdale School.[7] He is the youngest of three children.[8] Barn was offered a place to study natural sciences at University College London, but he ended up declining the offer in order to pursue his YouTube career full-time.[9]



## Career[edit]


Barn joined YouTube in 2010; having played games with his friends he got into watching YouTubers and making videos of their own. Eventually he decided to launch his own channel, stating:[10]




> I got involved thinking I might be able to do a little bit better than they were doing, and get involved and have some fun with it. I started recording myself playing *Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2*. I started making tutorial videos that people could watch – some of them were for knives and how you could throw them across the map. I made videos showing places where you could throw a knife or tomahawk and get a kill. I thought it would be cool to show off these ridiculous kills.
> 
> 


As his popularity increased, he began to take it more seriously, branching out into *Minecraft*.[10]


In 2013, he joined the Sidemen, which caused his popularity to rise further.[11] He would later move in with three other members, sharing a house with them from 2014 to 2018, when he announced he was moving out of the Sidemen House.[12][13] He is also part of the Dream SMP server.[14]


In January 2021, he announced on his channel that he was quitting playing *Call of Duty: Warzone* due to a proliferation of cheating,[15] saying hackers would be "the death of the game" if it went unfixed.[16] Along with criticism from several other high-profile streamers, the resulting uproar caused Activision to update the game's anti-cheat software.[17]



## Other ventures[edit]


Barn is an investor in esports teams and has spoken about how he has invested in London Royal Ravens, a *Call of Duty* team, speaking of his desire to 'build a blueprint' for the wider popularisation of the sport.[18]


On 28 September 2023, Barn released a single with Alan Walker and Dash Berlin titled "Better Off (Alone, Pt. III)" on digital platforms.[19]



## Personal life[edit]


In December 2021, Barn announced his engagement to his longtime girlfriend.[20] They got married in 2023.[21]

<fragment>

In October 2013, KSI signed with Maker Studios' sub-network, Polaris.[20] Since 19 October 2013, KSI has been part of the British YouTube group known as the Sidemen.[21][22][23] The group produces online videos, most often consisting of challenges, sketches and video-game commentary, as well as selling exclusive Sidemen merchandise.[24][25][26]


In 2015, KSI published a biography titled *KSI: I Am a Bellend*.[27] The book was released on 24 September 2015 in the UK and five days later in the United States, and KSI toured to support the book from its release until 4 October 2015.[28]


</fragment>

On 4 August 2017, KSI tweeted that he would be leaving the Sidemen, citing conflicts with fellow member, Ethan Payne.[*citation needed*] Shortly thereafter, he released a number of diss track videos criticising members of his then-former group, to which most of the members responded back with their own.[29] Later that month, KSI released a video in which he claimed that he was being deported from the United States for receiving an incorrect visa.[*citation needed*] In November 2017, KSI released a video discussing whether his supposed falling out with the Sidemen was real or fake, saying, "[the drama] wasn't entirely real but wasn't entirely fake either."[29]


In 2019, he was ranked second by *The Sunday Times* in its list of the top 100 UK influencers.[13] In 2020, *The Times* named KSI to be Britain's biggest influencer.[30]


</fragment>

**Olajide Olayinka Williams** "**JJ**" **Olatunji** (born 19 June 1993), known professionally as **KSI**, is an English Internet personality, professional boxer and musician. He is the CEO of Misfits Boxing and the co-owner of Prime Hydration, XIX Vodka, Sidemen Clothing, and a restaurant chain known as Sides.


</fragment>
<fragment>
English boxer, YouTuber and rapper (born 1993)

For other uses, see KSI (disambiguation).

</fragment>
<fragment>

KSI's rise to fame was not without controversy, with him being widely criticised for his self-described 'rape-face', a recurring joke on his channel during 2012 and 2013.[12] He was the centre of a controversy following third-party allegations of sexual harassment of female staff at a *Eurogamer* event in 2012, that went so far as accusing him of sexually assaulting a spokesmodel Brandy Brewer, despite her tweeting that she consented to the motorboat, writing, "it's called comedy……relax".[16][17] As a result, Microsoft cut ties with KSI and he was banned from *Eurogamer* events.[18] KSI subsequently apologised "for any offence the video of 15 months ago may have caused in the short time it was on his YouTube channel, references to it since and subsequently used by other people" and stated his desire to move on from the incident and "be judged on the great content and value he gives to brands and partners, without controversy."[19]



### 2013–present: Sidemen and expanding content[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

In March 2021, KSI faced criticism for misgendering a trans person and using a transphobic slur in a Sidemen video. He later apologised, claiming not to have known that the word was offensive.[31][32] In April 2023, KSI used the racial slur "*Paki* " in a Sidemen video parodying the British game show *Countdown*. He later apologised on Twitter and announced he was taking a break from social media. The video has since been removed.[33] He then visited the Al-Hikam Institute, a mosque in Bradford, to "educate himself" and where he apologised again for the hurt and disappointment he had caused.[34]


In September 2023, *Forbes* ranked KSI as the second top creator of 2023, earning an estimated $24 million.[35]



## Music career[edit]


### 2015–2016: Early releases[edit]


</fragment>

<fragment>

In 2020, *The Sunday Times* estimated KSI's earnings to be £12 million a year; a year later, they believed that his estimated earnings had gone up by another £13 million.[154][155]


He has been open about his investments in cryptocurrency, but he has reportedly lost almost £6 million. Since the losses, he has claimed to be done with crypto.[156]



## Philanthropy[edit]


In 2015, KSI donated $10,000 to an online charity stream done by YouTuber Castro1021, and he participated in the Race Against Slime event, raising money for SpecialEffect, a foundation developing technology to aid people with physical disabilities to play video games.[147] Between 2016 and 2022, KSI and the rest of the Sidemen hosted and participated in four charity football events, raising just shy of £400,000 for various charities, including the Saint's Foundation, Childline, Young Minds and the Charlton Athletic Community Trust.[157]

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Based on the search results, I can provide information about these members of the Sidemen:

1. Vikkstar123 (Vikram Singh Barn):
- Born August 2, 1995 in Guildford, Surrey, England
- British YouTuber and Internet personality
- Member and co-founder of the Sidemen
- Known for gaming content, particularly Call of Duty and Minecraft
- Has over 12.1 million subscribers across his YouTube channels
- Recently married to Ellie Harlow in 2023
- Has invested in esports teams including London Royal Ravens
- Released a music single with Alan Walker and Dash Berlin in 2023

2. KSI (Olajide Olayinka Williams "JJ" Olatunji):
- Born June 19, 1993 in London, England
- English Internet personality, professional boxer, and musician
- CEO of Misfits Boxing and co-owner of Prime Hydration, XIX Vodka, Sidemen Clothing, and Sides restaurant chain
- Has over 41.5 million subscribers combined across his channels
- Member of the Sidemen since October 2013
- Has had success in boxing, music, and various business ventures
- Ranked second by The Sunday Times in 2019 as one of UK's top influencers
- Estimated earnings of £25 million per year as of 2021

3. W2S:
- While a direct article wasn't found, he is mentioned as being one of the seven members of the Sidemen group

The Sidemen as a group produces online videos consisting of challenges, sketches and video-game commentary, and sells exclusive merchandise. They've also been involved in various projects including The Sidemen Show (2018) and charity football matches.
